awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Short Vectors in Lattices
awd_abstract_narration:
The main focus of this project is to rebuild the literature on lattice algorithms on a foundation of modern computer architecture. This means  going beyond counting textbook operations, and instead investigating the time required on a parallel machine with realistic limits on  communication, so as to obtain the ultimate implementation efficiency on  current and future chips. 
 
Major project activities include the following: 1. Fast constant-time  implementations of fundamental arithmetic operations such as integer  multiplication, Euclid's algorithm, and modular inversion. 2. A scalable parallelized implementation of the LLL lattice-basis-reduction algorithm for large-rank lattices. 3. Improvements to algorithms for finding   shorter vectors in lattices, including sieving, enumeration, and  multiplicative techniques from algebraic number theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project 1913167 discovered that "derandomization", a tool used in many
lattice-based cryptosystems to help protect against chosen-ciphertext
attacks, sometimes damages security. If a trillion ciphertexts are sent
to a FrodoKEM-640 public key then one of the ciphertexts will be broken
by a multi-ciphertext derandomization attack using just 2^88 guesses, a
feasible computation today for a large-scale attacker.

This attack contradicts the FrodoKEM claim that "the FrodoKEM parameter
sets comfortably match their target security levels with a large
margin". In response to this attack, a new patched version of FrodoKEM
was issued in 2023, while the original version of FrodoKEM was renamed
"ephemeral FrodoKEM". The patch does not rescue the claim.

As a deeper result, this project discovered another way to exploit the
shared structure of multiple ciphertexts sent to a lattice public key.
This also demonstrates a gap in an ACM CCS 2021 paper that claimed to be
able to prove that breaking one of many lattice ciphertexts is as
difficult as breaking a specific target ciphertext.

As another application of those techniques, this project discovered that
asymptotic attack exponents for lattice-based cryptosystems have not
stabilized. In particular, this project's optimization of "hybrid"
attacks contradicts the NewHope claim that these attacks are "induced
by the fact that secrets are ternary".

As its deepest result, in joint work, this project's investigations of
S-unit attacks broke through various limits claimed in the literature
for those attacks. See https://s-unit.attacks.cr.yp.to for details.

This project also initiated cryptographic risk analysis as a topic of
scientific study. For example, as a case study of quantifying failure
rates for cryptographic selection processes, this project has observed
that 48% of the round-1 submissions to the NIST post-quantum competition
in 2017 are broken by now; 25% of the submissions not broken during
round 1 are broken by now; and 36% of the submissions selected by NIST
in 2019 for round 2 are broken by now.

This project's final recommendation is that applications deploying
lattice-based cryptography (1) select the largest available lattice
dimensions and (2) use lattice-based cryptography as an extra layer on
top of ECC, rather than discarding ECC.


Last Modified: 01/13/2024
Modified by: Daniel J Bernstein
